API Gateway: AWS service that handles HTTP requests and routes them to backend services like Lambda functions
Lambda: Serverless compute service that runs code without managing servers. You write the code, AWS runs it.
DynamoDB: NoSQL database service provided by AWS. It's fast and scales automatically.
S3: Simple Storage Service - object storage in the cloud. Think of it like a file system in the cloud.
Cognito: AWS service for user authentication and authorization. Handles login, signup, and user management.
JWT: JSON Web Token - a secure way to transmit information between parties. Used for authentication.
Docker: Platform for running applications in containers. Makes it easy to run the same code everywhere.
Node.js: JavaScript runtime that lets you run JavaScript on the server side.
Express: Web framework for Node.js. Makes it easy to build APIs and web servers.
REST API: Representational State Transfer API - a way for applications to communicate over HTTP.
Endpoint: A specific URL path in an API that performs a specific function (like /auth/login).
Serverless: Architecture where you don't manage servers. AWS handles all the infrastructure.
IAM: Identity and Access Management - AWS service for managing permissions and access.
CloudWatch: AWS monitoring service. Shows logs and metrics for your applications.
VPC: Virtual Private Cloud - your own isolated network in AWS.
CI/CD: Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment - automated testing and deployment pipeline.
Git: Version control system for tracking code changes.
Pull Request: A way to propose code changes. Others review before merging into main code.
Merge: Combining code changes from one branch into another.
Branch: A separate version of your code where you can make changes without affecting the main code.
Environment Variables: Configuration values stored outside your code (like API keys).
JSON: JavaScript Object Notation - a format for storing and exchanging data.
HTTP Methods: GET (retrieve data), POST (create data), PUT (update data), DELETE (remove data).
Async/Await: JavaScript syntax for handling asynchronous operations (like API calls).
Promise: JavaScript object representing the eventual completion of an async operation.
Callback: Function passed as an argument to another function, called when operation completes.
Middleware: Code that runs between receiving a request and sending a response.
CORS: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing - allows web apps from different domains to communicate.
Authentication: Verifying who you are (login with username/password).
Authorization: Verifying what you're allowed to do (permissions).
Encryption: Converting data into a secret code to protect it.
Hash: One-way conversion of data (like passwords) into a fixed-size string.
Salt: Random data added to passwords before hashing to make them more secure.
Token: A piece of data that proves you're authenticated (like a digital key).
Session: A way to remember user state across multiple requests.
Cache: Temporary storage of data to make future requests faster.
Load Balancer: Distributes incoming traffic across multiple servers.
Scaling: Adding more resources to handle increased traffic (horizontal: more servers, vertical: bigger servers).
Deployment: Process of releasing your code to production where users can access it.
Rollback: Reverting to a previous version of code if something goes wrong.
Staging: Environment that mimics production for testing before release.
Production: Live environment where real users access your application.
Development: Environment where developers write and test code.
Bug: An error or flaw in code that causes incorrect behavior.
Debug: Process of finding and fixing bugs in code.
Refactor: Improving code structure without changing its behavior.
Technical Debt: Future work needed due to quick/suboptimal solutions now.
Sprint: Fixed time period (usually 2 weeks) for completing a set of tasks.
Standup: Daily short meeting where team shares progress and blockers.
Blocker: Something preventing you from making progress on a task.
Code Review: Process where other developers check your code before merging.
Linter: Tool that checks code for style and potential errors.
Unit Test: Test that checks a single piece of code works correctly.
Integration Test: Test that checks multiple pieces of code work together.
Mock: Fake version of a component used in testing.
Dependency: External code/library your project needs to work.
Package Manager: Tool for installing and managing dependencies (npm, yarn).
CLI: Command Line Interface - text-based way to interact with programs.
SDK: Software Development Kit - tools and libraries for building applications.
API Key: Secret code used to authenticate with an external service.
Webhook: Automated message sent from one app to another when something happens.
Rate Limiting: Restricting how many requests a user can make in a time period.
Pagination: Breaking large data sets into smaller pages.
Response Body: Data returned from an API request.
Cookie: Small piece of data stored in browser, sent with each request.
Local Storage: Browser storage that persists even after closing browser.
Session Storage: Browser storage that clears when tab is closed.
